text: so in this talk today i want to speak about how could we free the classroom from the confines of
its walls how could we design a classroom which gets better as more people participate how could we create a
global classroom and in doing so i want to take what we know about how people learn in in person classroom especially
in creative domains and build computational systems that scale out these techniques to tens of thousands of
people so over the last few years you've seen how millions of students have enrolled
in massive online classes and to me what the student interest shows about all is this enormous thirst for knowledge
and colleges and universities have been meeting the needs traditionally of the college demographic but what we see with
these new online classes is that the college demographic is just a tiny sliver of the population that's
interested in learning this these are the results from a large class cross-class survey in four online
classes with around 60 000 participants and you see that only a third of the participants in
these online classes call themselves students and the rest of them say i'm not a
student right so who are these people so if you look at class enrollment data you see
that only 20 percent of students say in the hci online class are traditional students and the vast
majority of them are students who you would not expect to see in an in-person college classroom
so now that we have the means to reach this enormously broader learner population the question to me is how
could we teach these tens of thousands of new learners effectively and today in this talk i'm going to
argue that there are three ingredients to teaching that we need to scale to this massive online world
and these are three ingredients that we see consistently across engineering our
design and other domains they're also really hard to scale because these are teaching processes
which rely on personal interactions between people that have been fostered by staff
so here's the first of those three interactions it's feedback on open-ended work whether you are in an art class and
you create hundreds and hundreds of sketches or you're learning how to program by writing your own code in an
intro programming class the crucial aspect to doing open-ended work is getting feedback on such work
however giving feedback requires expertise and this is a task that has fallen traditionally to staff
this doesn't scale to the online world for example if we just do what we do in the in-person class here at stanford
with the cs106a class for example we would spend 30 minutes per student per week giving them feedback with a
small online class of 5000 students this would take around three and a half percent months of effort each week
so that's the first ingredient that i believe we need to scale second we need to uh scale interactions with peers who
have diverse perspectives this could take for example the form of a model united nations or it could take the form
of a design critique in a on in-person design class what's central to both of these is that
students are speaking with other people who have opinions and perspectives that are different from their own
now students don't go around making friends with people who they disagree with right so staff have fostered these
interactions in the in-person world how do we scale out this scaffolding to the online world for the last in teaching
process i want to go back to the sketch i showed you a couple slides ago after nearly 200
revisions it became pablo picasso's famous painting the muslin
what picasso's example shows is the central importance of revision to
mastery her revision requires meaningful feedback
how do you provide meaningful feedback that requires expertise to tens of thousands of people online
so these are the three these are the three learning processes that i think we need
to scale to the online world and in the rest of my talk today i'm going to describe three systems that i've built
as part of my dissertation that target each of these three teaching processes
in general my approach to building of these systems is to take what we know about how people learn in the in-person
world essentially take what we know from learning theory and from psychology and create computational systems that
scale these techniques to thousands of students using techniques from human centered design and social computing
all of these systems that i'm describing to you today have been validated at scale as scott mentioned i have run
nearly 40 randomized controlled experiments which look at a variety of different aspects of learning
in the online classroom of course some of these experiments
ended up giving the results that we expected those are in green a large fraction of them had results which
surprised us and were the opposite of what we expected those are in red today in this talk i'm only going to
describe to you the results of 40 well a dozen or so of these 40 experiments
and those were run in classes taught by these universities
so while i was building these systems for the large online world it became apparent that the teaching processes
that scale to tens of thousands of people are also valuable in person context so in the tail end of my talk
i'll describe how some professors are using these tools in in-person classes at these universities
so the first system i want to describe to you today is one on global peer assessment and the impedance for the system came
about around three years ago when daphne caller was then a colleague at stanford and now of course the ceo at coursera
came to uh scott clemmer my advisor and i and said let's take the introductory hci class
that you run at stanford and open it up so that anybody on the internet can enroll in it
and while we thought through the challenges of doing so transforming instruction especially
lectures to an online format is relatively straightforward but transforming assessment is a lot more
challenging at the time we started most online classes had uh either simple multiple
choice type questions or they had completely automated assessments so if you're in a programming language or
machine learning class you'd write a piece of code you'd upload it to a server the server would then run either
automated tests or say static analysis on your code and then it would return to you a report which told you what you did
right and what you did wrong now this works well if you have a programmatic understanding of what
students wrote and what quality means but how does this work for a much more open-ended task for example this is a
typical hci assignment in this in this example a student is creating a storyboard which
shows how someone might use a prototype he plans to build in this case for for booking a doctor's appointment
now if you want to assess this kind of work you first have to parse the storyboard
but also you need real-world common sense knowledge for example you need to know that people want to meet their
doctors as soon as possible so encoding such real-world knowledge into
completely automated systems has been a long-standing challenge but
humans through their many years of experience have encoded this knowledge and so the insight that our assessment
system embodies is to simply ask students in the classroom to assess each other's work
it's somewhat a trivial insight that the number of students in a class scales with the size of the classroom
but coupled with this trivial insight is a problem and is that students are in your class because they're trying to
learn they don't have the expertise that teachers bring to the table when they're trying to assess student work
so the inside that are that that the system that we built
embodies is one of scaffolded micro expertise essentially our hypothesis was that even though students lack the broad
expertise of teachers in a constrained setting they can follow instruction instructor or articulated guidelines and
assess like instructors assess so to be honest i think the
the state of building large-scale scaffolded systems is still in its infancy and in some sense what we're
looking for are these design patterns which work at large scale and robustly so
we consider a number of design patterns let me show you one in this case we gave students a rubric
which told them how instructors would assess a particular piece of student work and then we asked them to use this
rubric to look at five other people five other classmates work they use the rubric assess their classmates and uh
and a student's grade was the aggregate grade of the grades that their uh their peers
assigned them we also added a second step where we ask students to self-assess use the same
rubric and look at their own work and assess it now
if you if the system worked well then both of these measures would correlate perfectly
everyone would use the same quality standard and therefore uh wait let me first show you how it
looks in an interface so here you go this is the storyboard and this is the rubric that the
instructor provided students choose a score they add a few comments if uh
which are optional okay so if if this worked perfectly then uh
the students self-grade and the grades that other students gave them would correlate perfectly so on this chart i
want to show you how well they correlated uh and here it is right on the x-axis of this chart is
the grade students gave themselves and the y-axis is the grade that other people gave them and this is actual data this is not a
matrix in which i'm going to plot the data so you can see that there's very minimal correlation
this is a design pattern which needs some work okay so what could we do we added a training step so in this case
what we did was we asked instructors to assess a small fraction of the submissions in the classroom and kt
submissions to students gave them the rubric that instructors used but did not tell them what grades instructors gave
each submission then students created these submissions independently and they got feedback as to whether they were
grading too high or too low so that they could self-correct students went through a number of these submissions and then we tacked on the
rest of our design pattern that i showed you before the the number of their classmates and they assess themselves
okay here's how well this works i showed you before uh the the case with no training
we try it in a different class now with training and we see much better correlation
now the question uh so now that it seems that we have much better correlation the next question we asked is are students
giving each other assessments which compare with stuff essentially how well do staff
instrument grades correlate and in order to find out what we did was we inserted a previously staffed created
submission in every student's grading pool students did not see this submission differently from any other
submission that they were grading but this gives us a data set of a small
number of staff assist submissions with a large number of student assessments now we can run a bootstrap simulation
which takes a small subset of each uh student assess uh small subset of assessments for each
student submission and then compare this uh the median grade from there to the staff grade by running this bootstrap
simulation multiple times we can get a robust estimate of how well student creates correlated staff grades
so we ran such a simulation and i'm going to show you the results for this past field class the two outcomes that we care
about in this class are are we passing the right students and are we not passing the right students right so here
is the first case these are students who would not have passed if they were graded by staff and you can see that
99.3 percent of the time they were not passed when they were graded by their classmates
the second question we might ask is would would you earn a certificate with uh pure peer reading if uh you would
have earned it if staff had graded you and here you see that 97.8 percent of the time students do get the
certificates that they deserve now there's a 2.2 percent failure rate here
and it sounds like a small percentage but of course because it's a large number of students uh it's still a
large number of people who are affected so i'm not going to describe uh other work that we've done in order to improve
this number and we can get this number down with some iterative improvements to this process
what i will want to what i do want to show you is the distribution of how peers and staff rate each submission so
this is a histogram and on the x-axis is the difference between the the median grade that peers gave uh a
particular student submission and the staff grade so also i
i put these two red lines here because if you ask the if you ask two staff members to create the same submission
they don't always agree this is as you would expect because this is open-ended work on average the difference between staff
was 6.7 percent of the total grade of the class of the of the assignment so we see that
with your rating 47 percent of uh student submissions have grades within
this uh staff variation and we see that around 65 percent of them have grades which are twice the
staff variation so it seems to work well for a pass field class but
there are obviously limitations one of them is a pretty fundamental limitation we are asking students to assess each
other using a rubric now if you have particularly creative work that falls outside the box
then your classmates may not know how to assess it here is one student who put it
rather eloquently so in in response to uh to student
comments like this we made a simple change which is we added a check box at the very end of our submission process
which said this was an out of the box submission so we could know both how how well the rubric worked and how we could
improve it so as i mentioned before we
this this this was a large-scale peer assessment process uh we piloted it in scott's
online hci class and since then it's been used in more than 100 different classes and more than 100 000 students
have submitted and rated each other's work using the system one consistent theme that we see across
all of these classes is how students find each other's work to be inspiring
for example here is a student here here are two examples from an
introduction to art class this is one particular assignment and on the left you see a painting of the northern
lights from norway and on the right is this installation art from armenia both of
which were instrument submissions in the same assignment in this class often when students saw something like
this they would say i've never seen something like that in real life now this is one of the greatest benefits
of online global classes but we also see a downside so students were blind to who they were
grading but we saw that students often gave grades which are a little lower to
students from different countries uh this this graph shows you that if you were from a different country you would
be rated around four percent lower than if you're in the same country as your peer assessor uh as as with all results
in this uh in the stock this is significant at the 0.05 level we see here that global diversity can be
both a huge asset as well as a huge risk so what this suggests to us is that if
we can structure these peer interactions carefully we can make diversity more of an asset and less of a
risk i'll speak about it in the next section of my talk but i quickly wanted to summarize the contributions from this
global peer assessment system and we saw that we can scale assessment through scaffolded micro expertise and
assessment can be both accurate as well as inspirational now we wanted i said i'll talk about
global diversity being both an asset and risk and to do that i want to describe the second
part of my dissertation a system called talk about this is a system which uses diversity as a design opportunity in
particular it creates diverse discussions for students from around the world so why care about diversity in this
particular system we are looking at two primary benefits of diversity first of all there are the informational benefits
when students from around the world talk to each other you get exposed to different educational systems different
ways of thinking as well as different cultural values in addition to this informational
gain you also have a cognitive gain when students speak to each other who are when students speak to similar others
they may think in a passive and automatic mode of thinking but by speaking to people who are unlike you
you're forced to engage in a more active and effortful manner of thinking which ultimately we hope will lead you to
question your assumptions and learn better now these are great benefits of
diversity and online classes are a great opportunity to leverage these benefits
here is aggregated gip data from around half a million students in four different
classes and you can see that people in online classes are enrolling from across
the world so there's an almost even distribution from different parts of the world here
now even though there's this great opportunity most students don't get to see any of these benefits of diversity
even when students do engage with each other on the forums we often see posts like this
where students are looking for others who are just like themselves who think similarly or speak the same language
now this isn't a new problem uh even in the in person classroom uh teachers have
had to foster diverse interactions either by creating for example cross-ability project teams or say
across background dorm rooms so the question to me is how
do we create the online equivalent of the multicultural dorm room and our answer is the system called talk
about which i'll describe to you right away so talk about as a system where students who are
enrolled in an online class get to pick a time when they are willing to speak with classmates from around the
world when you pick a time and arrive for the discussion talk about automatically
finds you four or five other people to speak with and
and you can engage in a discussion with diverse classmates from around the world on a system built on top of google
hangouts now it's important here that students get to pick a time of their convenience
because as i showed you before these are students who may have full-time jobs but it's also the case here that
students don't get to pick whom they speak with so this allows talk about to
algorithmically assign students to groups in particular we use a very very
simple greedy algorithm which assigns each student to one of many parallel groups
we try and optimize for the diversity in each group in in this case we use very simple
metrics of diversity in particular we look at geographical location that is the location of residents and we
look at gender different instructors may want different kinds of diversity in the classroom so
we allow instructors to pick how much they want to weigh either geography or gender
or to balance each geography agenda okay so
and now i want to show you how students participate in these discussions we we
conducted many many interviews with uh students who participated in uh these global discussions here is one of them
this is a student his name is lex he lives in australia and he took part in the organizational analysis class
as he speaks you can see how he gets to speak with people from different parts of the world who are different organizational experience
it's very flexible you get people from ukraine from india from swiss from south
africa they're coming all together in a very yeah open way
the first time there was also a lady from australia and she was working in the gambling industry she was very
evocative very well she was very um very bright
there was this guy from china as well that was recently he worked in geneva for the united nations
completely over frustrated by bureaucracy
when you meet all those people from over the whole world and coming together and discussing the same theories that's
really exciting right so lots and lots of students have
experiences just like lex in fact if you look at the discussion data you see that on
average the median number or rather the median number of uh countries represented in a six-person
discussion group is five and the median distance between participants is larger
than the distance between new york and london we also see that students discuss with their classmates much longer than we ask
them to so instructors created discussion agendas which are supposed to
fit a discussion of 30 minutes that's this green line here and you see that most students speak for much longer the
median duration was 58 minutes so we conducted interviews and participated in some of these
discussions to find out what was happening and one common reason was that instructors would often tell students
you can pick from one of two discussion topics and students would then pick the first discussion topic as a group and
then they would pick the second discussion topic as a group and continue their discussions
all right so so it seems like students seem to like these discussions i would
like to evaluate whether participating in these discussions helps in particular i want to look at two questions does
participating in a global discussion help and does a diversity in participants improve the benefits of of
participation okay to find out the answer to the first question we ran a controlled experiment
in the irrational behavior class uh this had around a thousand students and students
in this class when they signed up for talkabout were assigned to one of two between subjects conditions
in the waitlist conditions students were told talk about isn't ready for you yet come back four weeks later which was the
halfway point in the class the other half of the class who signed up for uh talk about was allowed to discuss uh our
participation discussions from the first week of class so this creates uh experimental setup
where half the students who are equally motivated have been prevented from participating in uh discussions so we
can control for the uh for the effects of motivation so to analyze the results we ran an
intention to repeat analysis oops sorry i forgot to tell you one important thing uh the the dependent measure that we
looked at in this class in this experiment was the total course grade that students had at the end of this class
so uh here are the results we ran an intention to read analysis for looking at our results and we see that
students were assigned to the discussion condition scored approximately six percent higher
than students who are assigned to the weightless condition so this could be for example because
you're spending more time thinking about class topics while they're participating in discussions so
we now ask does the diversity in participants improve the benefits of participation and to find out again we
ran a controlled experiment this time in the social psychology class with around 2 500 students and this was a quasi
experiment instead of assigning students greedily to the most diverse group available we assign students to the
first available group now this creates a condition where some students were assigned to more diverse uh discussions and others were assigned
to less diverse discussions as the measure of as a dependent measure
in this experiment we looked at the grade in the final exam which occurred a week after students participated in
these discussions because this discussion happened at a tail end of class we controlled for prior performance in the class as one of our
variables in our in our regression model okay so let me show you the results on
this chart on the y-axis is the difference between the average grade the average difference
the difference between the average grade of students who are assigned to the most diverse discussion group and the least diverse discussion group and in the
social psychology class we see that students assigned to the most diverse discussion group had grades which are two and a half percent higher than
students assigned to a least diverse discussion group uh these these are differences caused simply by assigning
students to different groups the everybody had the same agenda for discussion for example we repeated this
experiment in the organizational analysis class and we saw that students did around three and a half percent
better on each weekly quiz the week they participated in a discussion
so we see here that there uh that discussion uh participating in
discussions helps we also see that the diversity amongst participants in the discussion improves these benefits
while i was while we were deploying these systems we got several emails from students i want to show you one of them
because it i think highlights an important issue for future work this is my jamal she emailed me from
egypt last year and this was when you had the chaos and the uprisings in the riots in egypt and she was trying to
participate in this talk about discussion now you can see that she couldn't and we rescheduled her discussion to help her
out but i think there's an important point for future researchers to make sure that the systems that we build
provide equitable access to students from around the world still even with the systems that we have
today students are already using talk about as a springboard to create global friendships
in a post-discussion survey across nine classes we asked students did you share contact information with
the rest of your discussion group remember these are discussion partners who are assigned by an algorithm so they
did not know who they will be speaking with and we find that around 47 percent of students actually shared information such as
email in some classes this happened an overwhelming majority of the time for example in the
international women's health and human rights class we conducted follow-ons to find out why this was so and a common reason was
because students wanted to create a strong support network so that they could change the status quo
so far we've had more than 5 000 students used to talk about in the last year
and they've discussed a wide variety of topics one way students have
contributed back to the system is by translating it into different languages such as french spanish and there's one
more now but i forgot i've forgotten anyway so uh all right so uh
so uh to summarize in this section uh talk about is a system which uses diversity as a design opportunity and
creates small group discussions that are globally diverse it improves not just course grades but also
creates these new opportunities to form global friendships before i move on i wanted to thank julia who's here
she helped majorly in this project and uh she's not coursera so clearly she's
doing other things as well all right so uh in the last section of my talk today i i want to speak about
using scale as a design opportunity and in particular i want to describe the system called peer studio
but if you go back to the very start of my talk i spoke about how revision is central to mastery here is james dyson
who speaks about how it took him 15 years of his life and more than 5 000 prototypes to create the cyclone vacuum
cleaner now examples like james tyson's speak about how important it is to iterate and
design other researchers for example uh this is
anders ericsson who speaks about deliberate practice also talks about the importance of revision and more
importantly here the importance of giving and receiving immediate feedback on on on the work that you've created it
says for example students should receive immediate informative feedback and knowledge of results as they
as they practice repeatedly now there are some classroom techniques
which have created systems for revision and for public display of work the
probably the most well known is the design studio this is a place where students exhibit
their ongoing work and they can get feedback from both peers and from experts on on such work
but the design studio is limited by geography it can only accommodate so many people what if instead we want to create a
massive online studio where anybody on the internet could enroll and participate in particular our goal here is to create
a system which provides students on demand and immediate feedback on open-ended work at any time of day
the system that we created called view studio and here's how it works students can use peer studio to
get feedback on open-ended work in classrooms they can submit a drive for feedback give feedback to two other
classmates on similar work and immediately thereafter get feedback on their own work
they can use this feedback to revise their work any number of times until they're happy with it and get submitted
for grades so one way to build the system is to simply take what i described to you in the
first section of this talk on peer assessment and flip a bit which allows students to submit multiple times
we could do that but that has a problem and the problem is i told you how assessment training is crucial to
accuracy but assessment training also takes a lot of time for example in an assignment which took
students a median of ten and a half hours in the hci class students spent around two hours learning how to assess
each other now this is a cost that we might be willing to pay if we seek very accurate
assessments of final work but maybe we don't want to pay this cost when you're looking at draft work and
you're seeking early feedback so in particular the research question that we ask is how could we scaffold
this notion of micro expertise and spoke about in a way that doesn't require an explicit training step
and the solution that we came up with uses the the idea of contrasting cases
and in particular so perhaps i should explain first with an example so if you give me a glass of wine and ask me
shouldn't i describe this glass of wine i'm going to tell you it tastes like wine because i don't know much about wine
on the other hand if you give me two different kinds of wines and tell me can we compare these two glasses of wine
then i can start telling you one of them is more floral one of them is fruitier the other one tastes like pencil
shavings things like that so uh what this what this example shows
is to a novice like me comparing two artifacts which is superficially similar allows me to
understand the deeper non-superficial structure of each artifact this is how your studio embodies this
insight into an interface this is a student work that peers are asked to give feedback on as before we
augmented with the rubric which the instructor provides in this case we also augmented with an instructor curated
example of excellent work the way students assess in peer studio
is to compare student work to the instructor provided example across a number of dimensions
then they mark off their assessments on a rubric and uh
which is over here sorry yeah so we tried this assessment process in a in
a pilot and a small in person class and we found that on average students the majority of students and the staff
disagree around 5.7 percent of the time so this is accurate enough to give
students quick feedback without a explicit training step now the other part of getting quick
feedback is getting someone to give you that feedback so how do you recruit reviewers quickly in this case the
massiveness of the online class is a friend and in particular peer studio use a dual recruitment
strategy when it detects that other people are online it simply asks the next student who comes online to review
your work in cases where we detect that few people are online for example if you're in a
time zone where few people have submitted work then we'll start recruiting reviewers for your email we
stop recruiting immediately after we've recruited enough people so we tried this recruitment scheme in a
large online class they're learning how to learn class and here's how how quickly students got feedback uh and the
x-axis is the time to the first review and you see that a vast number of students got feedback within
10 minutes the average time sorry the median time to feedback was 20 minutes in this class
and less than four percent of students had to wait longer than 24 hours to get feedback
so here's the life of a median student who is using peer studio they create their essay for example in this class uh
by using this online editor they submit this for feedback they give feedback to two other students using the uh the
interface i showed you earlier on average that is on median students take nine minutes to give each of the
feedback so 18 minutes later they're done giving feedback to two other of the classmates they wait two minutes and
they get feedback from their uh from their classmates on their own work this is how that looks
now they can use this feedback a to revise any number of times until they're happy with their submission and then
they submit it for a grade so we built the system and we were very
happy with the accuracy of the feedback that students had and we're happy with the time how quickly how students got
their feedback and then we discovered a problem and the problem was that even though
feedback can be accurate it's not always actionable and to illustrate i want to show you this one example of a student
essay which a professional teacher annotated there is an essay on the super bowl and if you're in the back you may
not be able to see what the student has written not this teacher's comments but you can see it's pretty heavily marked
up right so for example in the first line the teacher says be more precise be
less wordy use a comma here so looking at feedback like this you might think this student's work is
nearly complete all it needs is a few grammatical fixes and then you look in the margins and
then you say it says you need to do more research so
essentially this invalidates the rest of the comments that the teacher has made because you have to toss away what
you've written and start over again what you'd like instead is a system which gives students the most actionable
feedback at any time during the process and we know from feedback theory some
things that could help for example we know that feedback which gives the information and correctness what you've
done right and velocity which way you should move and what you should do is
is very effective we also know that feedback that is specific and uh
is related to your topic is a lot more relevant than general truisms about how you should do work
now we can encode these into an interface and in particular i built a
system which gives students real time tips for as they're writing comments for each other
and it uses for example a logistic regression model which predicts for example if the comments that you're
writing are topically relevant to the student work it uses a simple bag of word features
and word overlap for example here okay so here's how it looks like in practice here's a rubric i showed you
before and in this rubric green means good and red means needs work
uh what we do here is compute a score uh based on how you marked up the rubric
and then we make a suggestion for you what you should say in this case we say that this looks
mostly good except for this last part how would you improve it if things didn't look quite as good we
would say what's the first thing you would suggest to improve this other students might see uh prompts like
be more specific as to what the students should change if we decide that they're being too vague
so we had a ta independently read the comments that students wrote and you see
that 81 percent of student submissions had feedback that the ta rated as actionable
interestingly here students rated their feedback to be actionable much more frequently than tas
did so all right so here's here are some of the changes that we see when we use a system
which provides real-time tips without hints students tended to focus mostly on the
author of the work and what they've done well so we saw engrams like i think you are on the
right track for example or i will i i wish you good luck or even bizarrely i
hope you have a nice day with tips on the other hand we found
that students tended to focus much more on the work itself and how it could be improved
we saw words like i think you should change something or i need i think you need to do something or your work could
improve by doing something now of course it doesn't work all the time uh students are often stumped for
what they should tell people who are already very good uh this is a real student comment for example but overall
we want to know if the feedback that students give each other helps them improve their work and to find out we ran a
between subject's experiment in the medical education class start here at stanford it used uh well it had
it had 104 students who consented to be in this experiment and it had three between subjects conditions the first
was a no early feedback condition where students were not allowed to revise the work this was the standard classroom
condition where you'd do the best work you could and you'd submit it someone would then review your work and then
give your score then we added a second condition where students were allowed to revise any
number of times but they would only get feedback 24 hours or later after they submitted
so uh i'm sorry exactly 24 hours after this were made and this control condition i call it the
enthusiastic ta condition so the ta stays up overnight and gives you feedback
and in the last condition we had students get feedback as quickly as possible as quickly as the peer studio
system could provide them in this case the median student got feedback in less than an hour
okay so when we looked at the results we see that the early feedback condition had grades
which were on average four and a half percent higher than students who were not allowed to revise
so you can see here the benefits of early early and fast feedback on improvements
and course grades we also found that students who got early feedback which
was delayed by 24 hours had grades which are statistically indistinguishable from
students who had no opportunity to revise at all so this is the enthusiastic ta condition
in particular so what when we look at our data one reason why we think this might happen is because we students
